{{Other uses2|One Man Band}} [[File:One man band, CDV by Knox, c1865.JPG|thumb|One-man band; photo by Knox of [[Athol, Massachusetts]], circa 1865]]
A '''one-man band''' is a musician who plays a number of instruments simultaneously using their hands, feet, limbs, and various mechanical or electronic contraptions. One-man bands also often sing while they perform.
The simplest type of "one-man band" is a singer [[accompaniment|accompanying]] themselves on [[acoustic guitar]] and playing a [[harmonica]] mounted in a metal "harp rack" below the mouth. This approach is often taken by [[busker]]s and [[folk music]] singer-guitarists. More complicated setups may include [[wind instrument]]s strapped around the neck, a large [[bass drum]] mounted on the musician's back with a beater which is connected to a foot pedal, [[cymbal]]s strapped between the knees or triggered by a pedal mechanism, [[tambourine]]s and [[maraca]]s tied to the limbs, and a stringed instrument strapped over the shoulders (e.g., a [[banjo]], [[ukulele]] or [[guitar]]).
Since the development of [[Musical Instrument Digital Interface]] (MIDI) in the 1980s, musicians have also incorporated chest-mounted MIDI drum pads, foot-mounted [[electronic drum]] triggers, and electronic [[pedal keyboard]]s into their set-ups. In the 2000s and 2010s, the availability of affordable digital looping pedals has enabled singer-musicians to record a riff or chord progression and then solo or sing over it.
==History and meanings== ===Live instruments=== [[Image:Cantigastaborers.gif|thumb|[[Pipe and tabor]]ers, from the 13th-century [[illuminated manuscript]], [[Cantigas de Santa Maria]]]] The earliest known records of multiple musical instruments being played at the same time date from the 13th century, and were the pipe and [[Tabor (instrument)|tabor]]. The pipe was a simple three-holed [[flute]] that could be played with one hand; the tabor is more commonly known today as a [[snare drum]]. This type of playing can still be heard in parts of rural [[France]], in [[England]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pipeandtabor.org|title=Pipe and Tabor - The home of The Taborers Society|author=|date=|website=Pipeandtabor.org|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> and [[Spain]]. An [[Elizabethan]]-era woodcut shows a clown playing the pipe and tabor. An 1820s watercolour painting shows a one-man band with a rhythm-making stick, panpipes around his neck and a [[bass drum]] and tambourine beside him. [[Henry Mayhew]]'s history of London street life in the 1840s and 1850s described a blind street performer who played bells, the violin and accordions.{{clarify|date=April 2014}}<ref>Henry Mayhew, London Labor and the London Poor, ([[Dover Publications]], Inc., New York, 1968), Vol. 3, p. 161. Reprint of 1861-62 edition published by Griffin, Bohn and Company.</ref>
Guitarist [[Jim Garner (musician)|Jim Garner]] played guitar with his hands and triangle with his feet, and [[Will Blankenship]] of the Blankenship Family of North Carolina played harmonica, [[autoharp]] and triangle in shows during the 1930s. In the 1940s, entertainer and clown [[Benny Dougal]] used a crude "stump fiddle" (a single string stretched on a stick) with a footpedal-operated pair of cymbals. [[Blues]] singers such as "Daddy Stovepipe" (Johnny Watson) would sing, play guitar, and stomp their feet for rhythm, or used a foot pedal to play bass drum or cymbal.
One of the earliest modern exponents of multiple instruments was [[Jesse Fuller]]. Fuller developed a foot-operated bass instrument which he called the "[[footdella]]", which had six bass strings which were struck by hammers. In "one-man-band" shows, Fuller would use his "footdella", a footpedal-operated "sock" (bass drum), a homemade neck harness (for a harmonica, [[kazoo]] and microphone), and a [[12-string guitar]]. [[Fate Norris]], of the [[Skillet Lickers]], a hillbilly string band of the 1920s and early 1930s developed a geared mechanical contraption with footpedals that enabled him to play guitar, bells, [[bass fiddle]], [[fiddle]], autoharp and mouth harp.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}
Joe Barrick, who was born in Oklahoma in 1922, wanted a way of accompanying himself on fiddle, so he built a contraption with a guitar neck on a board with footpedals to operate the notes. Subsequent versions of this "piatar" also had bass guitar and banjo necks and a snare drum which are played by foot-operated hammers. To change notes on the guitar-family instruments, a foot treadle operates a mechanical fretting device. Two notable one-man [[blues]] bands active in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]] in the 1950s were [[Doctor Ross]] and [[Joe Hill Louis]], playing guitar, harmonica and bass drum/[[Hi-hat (instrument)|high-hat]]. [[Image:Guitarist Liverpool Street.JPG|thumb|A musician in London performs on electric guitar and a small drum kit.]] The simple [[guitar]] and [[harmonica]] combination (as used by such musicians as [[Tex Williams]], [[Anton Newcombe]], [[Jimmy Reed]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Neil Young]], and [[Ray Dorset]] of [[Mungo Jerry]]) is so common now that it is rarely considered to be a one-man band. British-born [[Don Partridge]] made the classic one-man band outfit (bass drum on the back, guitar and harmonica) famous in the streets of [[Europe]], and was an early busker to enter the [[Top 40|Top Ten]] of the [[UK Singles Chart]], with his [[chart hit|hit]] [[single (music)|singles]] "Rosie" and "Blue Eyes" in 1968. Modern one-man bands include such performers as Ben de la Garza,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/bendelagarza|title=Ben de la Garza|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=9 October 2018}}</ref> [[Hasil Adkins]] and [[Sterling Magee]], better known as "Mister Satan," from [[Satan and Adam]]. [[Image:Onemanband.jpg|left|thumb|[[Vic Ellis]] of [[Sussex]]]]
:"The one-man band exists, in all its uniqueness and independence, as a most elusive yet persistent musical tradition. As a category of musicianship it transcends cultural and geographic boundaries, spans stylistic limits, and defies conventional notions of technique and instrumentation. Defined simply as a single musician playing more than one instrument at the same time, it is an ensemble limited only by the mechanical capabilities and imaginative inventiveness of its creator, and despite its generally accepted status as an isolated novelty, it is a phenomenon with some identifiable historical continuity."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mustrad.org.uk/articles/barrick.htm|title=Joe Barrick's one-man band|author=Hal Rammel |date=1990|website=Mustrad.org.uk|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref>
===Studio recording=== The term "one-man band" is also [[colloquialism|colloquially]] used to describe a performer who plays every instrument on a recorded song one at a time, and then mixes them together in a multitrack [[recording studio|studio]]. While this approach to recording is more common in electronica genres such as [[techno]] and [[acid house]] than traditional rock music, some rock performers such as [[Joe Hill Louis]], [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[Paul McCartney]], [[Kabir Suman]], [[Dave Edmunds]], [[John Fogerty]], [[Emitt Rhodes]], [[Todd Rundgren]], [[Steve Winwood]], [[Roy Wood]], [[Nik Kershaw]], and [[Les Fradkin]] have made records in which they play every instrument (one after the other). [[Mike Oldfield]] was noted for using this recording technique during the recording of his 1973 album ''[[Tubular Bells]]''. Other examples of a one-man band in the recording studio are [[Dave Grohl]] for the first studio album by the [[Foo Fighters]], [[Trent Reznor]] for [[Nine Inch Nails]], jazz piano player [[Keith Jarrett]] for his album ''[[No End (album)|No End]]'', [[Peter Tagtgren]] for [[Pain (musical project)]], [[Chris Carrabba]] for the first two albums released by [[Dashboard Confessional]], [[Varg Vikernes]] for [[Burzum]] and [[Billy Corgan]] for [[Smashing Pumpkins]] since 2009.
[[Nash the Slash]] (1948-2014) played all instruments on his recordings. He also played solo concerts from 1975 to 2012, using synchronized [[drum machine]]s and [[synthesizer]]s as he plays either an [[electric violin]] or [[electric mandolin]].{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} Some artists record and mixed their music in a multitrack studio and synchronize it with video multitrack video playing on all instruments, creating a one-man band illusion.
One-man bands in this context have become more common in [[extreme metal]], especially [[black metal]], where a number of bands apart from Burzum consist of only one member. Such artists include [[Nargaroth]], [[Xasthur]], [[Falkenbach]], [[Arckanum]], [[Nortt]], [[Horde (band)|Horde]], and others. While most of these bands do not play live, some such as [[Nargaroth]] hire additional musicians for live performances.
"One-woman band" is not used very often in the vernacular, but women have increasingly had a presence as musicians in most forms of music. Examples of one-woman bands are [[Merrill Garbus]], who performs as [[Tune-Yards]] and plays every instrument on all recordings {{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}, and [[Edith Crash]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://coachellavalleyweekly.com/joshua-tree-music-festival-2017-higher-purpose-in-the-high-desert/ |title=Joshua Tree Music Festival 2017 – Higher Purpose in the High Desert|website=Coachellavalleyweekly.com|accessdate=9 October 2018}}</ref> who creates "dark and haunting, drawn-out melodies"<ref>[http://laist.com/2016/08/18/echo_park_rising_2016.php Your Guide To The 2016 Echo Park Rising Festival<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105171548/http://laist.com/2016/08/18/echo_park_rising_2016.php |date=2017-11-05 }}</ref>.

===Live looping=== [[File:Chris Lejeune - One-Man-Band.jpg|thumbnail|Chris Lejeune 2007]] {{Main|Live looping}} In the 2000s, as digital looping pedals became widely available, performers have been able to use a mixture of previously recorded music, delay effects, and looping devices in live performances of everything from [[beatboxing]] to classical violin. Live looping performers create layered looped accompaniment for musical solos that are sung or played later in the song. Using this technology, a simultaneous combination of various instruments and vocals, or one instrument played in different ways, can be created over the course of one musical piece which rivals the sounds of studio recording. Notable artists who incorporate this technique live include [[Ed Sheeran]], [[Keller Williams]], [[That 1 Guy]], [[Zach Deputy]], and [[KT Tunstall]]. Rick Walker<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.looppool.info/bio.html|title=Loop.pooL: Rick Walker's musical biography|author=|date=|website=Looppool.info|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> is another looper and multi-instrumentalist who has organized looping festivals, including a long-running annual one in Santa Cruz, California, and others in various countries.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}
==Developments== [[File:ClarkeAndTheHimselfs.jpg|thumb|Clarke and the Himselfs<ref>[http://treefortmusicfest.com/lineup/67|title=treefortmusicfest.com/lineup/67] {{dead link|date=October 2018}}</ref> performing with mixed technology in [[Boise, Idaho]] in late 2013]] Since the development of Musical Instrument Digital Interface ([[MIDI]]) in the 1980s, musicians have also incorporated chest-mounted [[MIDI]] drum pads, foot-mounted electronic drum triggers. Some "one-man bands" use organ-style [[pedal keyboard]]s to perform [[bassline]]s. A small number of MIDI enthusiasts use custom-made MIDI controllers connected to different parts of their bodies to trigger music on synthesizers. Custom-made MIDI controllers range from wind-operated controllers to small triggers mounted on the arms or feet. At a certain point, the use of body MIDI controllers may come to resemble [[performance art]], because the musical sounds are triggered by the performer assuming certain poses or dancing. One of the pioneers of this performance art is McRorie Live Electronic, who uses drum sensors on his shoes, tom sensors on his chest, separate rhythm and bass keyboards and vocal lead instruments.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FgbUsJCfDf4|title=McPromo||date=23 October 2014|accessdate=18 April 2018|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref>
With the use of 2000s-era digital [[loop pedal]]s, which can record and then repeat a short musical phrase, performers can play a [[riff]] or [[groove (music)|groove]] and then solo over the repeated loop. An example of this technique is by Canadian musician Jay Robinson who creates full band arrangements live.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/jasonr123guitar|title=Jay Robinson|author=|date=|website=YouTube|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> [[Image:Dan the One man band Calgary.jpg|thumb|A one-man band [[busking]] in Calgary, Alberta]]
With the rise in availability and affordability of electronic devices came innovation with the traditional acoustic "one-man band" instruments. One example is the Farmer Musical Instrument Co! based in the US.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://footdrums.com|title=Farmer Foot Drums|author=|date=|website=Farmer Foot Drums|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> Pete Farmer sells acoustic foot-played percussion instruments that allow musicians to play a range of traditional drum kit sounds, the [[foot drum]] Deluxe, or tambourine and shaker pedals for tapping out simple beats. With the development of technology and prominence of video sharing sites like [[YouTube]], musicians are now able to record each instrument individually and then compile a video as if it were all done in real time.
==Non-musical meanings== The term is also used in a general sense to refer to a person who runs a [[small business]] alone (a sole-proprietorship business), particularly if the operation requires that person to assume multiple different roles, in a manner akin to the way a musical "one-man band" performer plays different instruments and sings at the same time. In some small businesses, the owner also produces the product or service, markets it and delivers it to clients. In TV news, the phrase refers to a reporter who also functions as her own cameraperson via the use of a tripod.
In 2011, professional wrestler [[Heath Slater]] climbed to fame with the nickname "The One-Man Rock Band", which was later changed to "The One-Man Southern Rock Band" in reference to him being billed from [[West Virginia]].

[[File:Adolf Loos (1870–1933) (vor 1920; Franz Löwy).jpg|thumb|Adolf Loos]] "'''Ornament and Crime'''" is an essay and lecture by modernist architect [[Adolf Loos]] that criticizes [[ornament (art)|ornament]] in useful objects.
==History== Contrary to popular belief that it was composed in 1908, Adolf Loos first gave the lecture in 1910 at the Akademischer Verband für Literatur und Musik in Vienna. The essay was then published in 1913 in ''Les Cahiers d’aujourd’hui'' in French as "Ornement et Crime". Only in 1929 was the essay published in German in the ''[[Frankfurter Zeitung]]'', as "Ornament und Verbrechen". It was the architect [[Henry Kulka]], who assisted Loos during a reprint of the essay in 1931 in ''Trotzdem'', that altered the original year to 1908 after he consulted Loos, who either didn't remember well or wanted to assume primacy in the confrontation against the [[Secession (art)|Secessionists]].<ref>Christopher Long, [http://apps.acsa-arch.org/resources/proceedings/uploads/streamfile.aspx?path=ACSA.AM.85&name=ACSA.AM.85.107.pdf “Ornament, Crime, Myth, and Meaning”], ''85th ACSA Annual Meeting Proceedings, Architecture: Material and Imagined'', 1997.</ref>
==Content== The essay was written when [[Art Nouveau]]—known as [[Vienna Secession|Secession]] in Austria and which Loos had excoriated even at its height in 1900—was showing a new way forward for modern art. The essay is important in articulating some moralizing views, inherited from the [[Arts and Crafts movement]], which would be fundamental to the [[Bauhaus]] design studio, and would help define the ideology of [[Modern architecture|modernism in architecture]].
"The evolution of culture marches with the elimination of ornament from useful objects," Loos proclaimed, thus linking the optimistic sense of the linear and upward progress of cultures with the contemporary vogue for applying [[evolution]] to cultural contexts.<ref>Jimena Canales, Andrew Herscher, [http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~hsdept/bios/docs/canales-Criminal%20Skins.pdf "Criminal Skins: Tattoos and Modern Architecture in the Work of Adolf Loos"], ''Architectural History'' 48, 2005.</ref> Loos's work was prompted by regulations he encountered when he designed a tailorshop without ornamentation next to a palace. He eventually conceded to requirements by adding a flowerpot.<ref name=nyt>{{cite news |last=Wise|first=Michael |date=4 December 2013 |title=Reassessing an Uproar in Architecture |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/05/garden/reassessing-an-uproar-in-architecture.html?_r=0 |newspaper=New York Times |location=New York |access-date=27 July 2016}}</ref>
In the essay, Loos explains his philosophy, describing how ornamentation can have the effect of causing objects to go out of style and thus become obsolete. It struck him that it was a crime to waste the effort needed to add ornamentation, when the ornamentation would cause the object to soon go out of style. Loos introduced a sense of the "immorality" of ornament, describing it as "degenerate", its suppression as necessary for regulating modern society. He took as one of his examples the [[tattoo]]ing of the "[[Papuan peoples|Papuan]]" and the intense surface decorations of the objects about him—Loos says that, in the eyes of western culture, the Papuan has not evolved to the moral and civilized circumstances of modern man, who, should he tattoo himself, would either be considered a criminal or a degenerate.<ref>{{cite book|author=Adolf Loos|year=1908|url=http://www2.gwu.edu/~art/Temporary_SL/177/pdfs/Loos.pdf|title=Ornament and Crime|location=Innsbruck, reprint Vienna, 1930|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403175309/http://www2.gwu.edu/~art/Temporary_SL/177/pdfs/Loos.pdf|archivedate=2015-04-03|df=}}</ref><ref name=rawson>{{cite book | last = Rawson | first = Jessica | |authorlink= Jessica Rawson |title = Chinese ornament: the lotus and the dragon | publisher = British Museum Publications | location = London | year = 1984 | isbn = 0-7141-1431-6 |page=19}}</ref>
Loos never argued for the complete absence of ornamentation, but believed that it had to be appropriate to the type of material.<ref name=nyt/>
Loos concluded that "No ornament can any longer be made today by anyone who lives on our cultural level ... Freedom from ornament is a sign of spiritual strength".<ref name=rawson/>

{{Distinguish|Paharia language (disambiguation){{!}}Paharia language}} '''Pahari''', or '''Pahadi''' ({{lang|hi|पहाड़ी}} {{lang|inc|pahāṛī}} 'of the hills/mountains'; {{IPAc-en|lang|p|ə|ˈ|h|ɑː|r|i}})<ref>{{Cite OED|Pahari}}</ref> is an ambiguous term that has been used for a variety of languages, dialects and language groups, most of which are found in the lower Himalayas.
Most commonly, it refers to: * [[Pahari-Pothwari]], the predominant language of Pakistan-administered Kashmir and neighbouring areas of Punjab and Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir * individual [[Himachali languages]], spoken in the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh<ref name="Masica1991">{{Cite book| last = Masica| first = Colin P.|author-link = Colin Masica| title = The Indo-Aryan languages| series = Cambridge language surveys| date = 1991| publisher = Cambridge University Press| isbn = 978-0-521-23420-7| page = 439| ref = harv}}</ref> * [[Northern Indo-Aryan languages]], in the linguistics literature often referred to as "Pahari languages", a controversial group that includes the Indo-Aryan languages of Nepal and the Indian states of [[Uttarakhand]] and [[Himachal Pradesh]].
Less commonly, ''Pahari'' may be: * a term used by [[Dogri language|Dogri]] speakers of the plains to refer to the Dogri varieties spoken at higher elevations, in Indian Jammu and Kashmir<ref>{{cite report|last1 = Brightbill| first1 = Jeremy D.| last2= Turner| first2 = Scott D.| year = 2007 | title = A sociolinguistic survey of the Dogri language, Jammu and Kashmir| series = SIL Electronic Survey Reports| url = https://www.sil.org/resources/publications/entry/9015| page = 7}}</ref> * a local name for a variety of [[Bilaspuri]] spoken in a certain hilly area of [[Indian Punjab]]<ref name="Masica1991"/> * a name nowadays used only in rural areas to refer to the [[Nepali language]]<ref>{{Cite book| last = Riccardi| first = Theodore| editors = George Cardona, Dhanesh Jain (eds.)| date = 2003| title = The Indo-Aryan languages| chapter = Nepali| series = Routledge language family series. Y| publisher = Routledge| location = London| page = 540| isbn = 978-0-7007-1130-7| ref = harv |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=C9MPCd6mO6sC}}</ref> * a local name for a [[Bhili language|Bhili]] dialect of Eastern [[Gujarat]].<ref name="Masica1991"/>
A similar term is ''Pahari'' ({{lang|ne|पहरी}}), which refers to a group of dialects of the Tibeto-Burman [[Newar language]] of Nepal.<ref>{{Cite book| last = van Driem| first = George| date = 2001| title = Languages of the Himalayas| series = Handbuch der Orientalistik| volume = 1| publisher = Brill| location = Leiden| isbn = 978-90-04-10390-0| pp = 758, 1098|ref = harv}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book| last = Shreshtha| first = Rudra Laxmi| year = 2003| chapter = Verbal morphology of the Badikhel Pahari dialect of Newar| title = Themes in Himalayan languages and linguistics| editor-last1 = Kansakar| editor-first1 = Tej Ratna| editor-last2 = Turin| editor-first2 = Mark| publisher = South Asia Institute ; Tribhuvan University| location = Heidelberg ; Kathmandu| isbn = 978-99933-54-16-1| pages = 145–62| ref = harv}}</ref>
Of similar origin is the name ''Paharia'', which is used for [[Paharia language (disambiguation)|several languages]] of east-central India.

{{Orphan|date=March 2014}} [[File:Young male chimp.png|thumb|280px|right|Many animals express individual behavioral traits that are stable over time and context]]
'''Personality in animals''' has been investigated across a variety of different scientific fields including; [[agricultural science]], [[Ethology|animal behaviour]], [[anthropology]], [[psychology]], [[veterinary medicine]], and [[zoology]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Gosling|first=S. D.|date=January 2001|title=From mice to men: what can we learn about personality from animal research?|journal=Psychological Bulletin|volume=127|issue=1|pages=45–86|issn=0033-2909|pmid=11271756}}</ref> Thus, the definition for animal personality may vary according to the context and scope of study. However, there is recent consensus in the literature for a broad definition that describes animal personality as individual differences in behaviour that are consistent across time and ecological context.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Wolf|first=Max|last2=Weissing|first2=Franz J.|title=Animal personalities: consequences for ecology and evolution|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tree.2012.05.001|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=27|issue=8|pages=452–461|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2012.05.001}}</ref> Here, consistency refers to the repeatability of behavioural differences between individuals and not a trait that presents itself the same way in varying environments.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Réale|first=Denis|last2=Reader|first2=Simon M.|last3=Sol|first3=Daniel|last4=McDougall|first4=Peter T.|last5=Dingemanse|first5=Niels J.|date=2007-05-01|title=Integrating animal temperament within ecology and evolution|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1469-185X.2007.00010.x|journal=Biological Reviews|language=en|volume=82|issue=2|pages=291–318|doi=10.1111/j.1469-185x.2007.00010.x|issn=1469-185X}}</ref><ref name="Stamps">{{cite journal|author1=Stamps, J.|author2=Groothuis, T.G.|lastauthoramp=yes|year=2010|title=The development of animal personality: relevance, concepts and perspectives|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Judy_Stamps/publication/40448467_The_development_of_animal_personality_relevance_concepts_and_perspectives/links/53dbd0350cf216e4210c01a5.pdf|journal=Biological Reviews|volume=85|issue=2|pages=301–325|doi=10.1111/j.1469-185x.2009.00103.x|pmid=19961473}}</ref>
Animal personality traits are measurable and are described in over 100 species.<ref name="Carere">{{cite journal|author1=Carere, C. |author2=Locurto, C. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2011|title=Interaction between animal personality and animal cognition|journal=Current Zoology|volume=57|pages=491–498 |doi=10.1093/czoolo/57.4.491}}</ref> Personality in animals has also been referred to as animal disposition, coping style, and temperament.<ref name=":2" /> There are also personality norms through the species, often found between genders.<ref name="Gosling2008" /> The diversity of animal personality can be compared in cross-species studies, demonstrating its pervasiveness in the evolutionary process of animals.<ref name=":2" /> Research on animal personality variation has been burgeoning since the mid 1990s.<ref name="Kralj">{{cite journal|author1=Kralj-Fišer, S.|author2=Schuett, W.|lastauthoramp=yes|year=2014|title=Studying personality variation in invertebrates: Why bother?|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=91|pages=41–52|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2014.02.016}}</ref> Recent studies have focused on its [[proximate causation]] and the [[Ecology|ecological]] and [[evolution]]ary significance of personality in animals.<ref name="Stamps" />
__TOC__
== Animal personality vs. human personality == The extent of personality phenomenon considered when examining animal personality is significantly reduced compared to those studied in humans. Concepts such as personal objects, identity, attitudes and life stories are not considered relevant in animals. Similarly, any approach that requires the subject to explain motives, beliefs or feelings is not applicable to the study of animal behaviour.<ref name=":2" />
The study of animal personality is largely based on the observation and investigation of behavioural traits. In an ecological context, traits or ‘characters’ are attributes of an organism that are shared by members of a species. Traits can be shared by all or only a portion of individuals in a population. For example, studies in animal personality often examine traits such as aggressiveness, avoidance of novelty, boldness, exploration and sociality.<ref name=":0" />
==Background== The initial framework used to study animal personality was [[comparative psychology]]. The descriptive language used by comparative psychologists in the late nineteenth century often attributed disposition and behavioural tendencies to individual animals in their studies. Many of these reports are the result of researchers anthropomorphizing the animal subjects and did not explicitly examine what is now considered animal personality. However, these studies do represent the some of the first instances of scientists reporting individual differences in animal behaviour.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-59300-5_1|title=Personality in Nonhuman Animals|last=Whitham|first=Will|last2=Washburn|first2=David A.|date=2017|publisher=Springer, Cham|isbn=9783319592992|pages=3–16|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-59300-5_1}}</ref>
The Russian physiologist, [[Ivan Pavlov]], was one of the first researchers to integrate personality into his research of animal behaviour. In his seminal studies on conditional reflexes, he categorized the behaviour of dogs as Excitable, Lively, Quiet or Inhibited. He linked these personalities to learning ability. The Excitable type, for example, showed signs of strong excitatory conditioning, but a limited ability for the acquisition of inhibitory connections. The Lively type was the most balanced and displayed rapid [[associative learning]], while the Quiet type exhibited consistent but slow learning.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carere|first=Claudio|last2=Locurto|first2=Charles|date=2011-08-01|title=Interaction between animal personality and animal cognition|url=https://doi.org/10.1093/czoolo/57.4.491|journal=Current Zoology|language=en|volume=57|issue=4|pages=491–498|doi=10.1093/czoolo/57.4.491|issn=1674-5507}}</ref>
The first study that empirically examined animal personality was in 1938, Meredith Crawford quantified individual differences in the behaviour of young chimpanzee using a behaviour rating scale. Crawford conducted his research out of the Yale Laboratories of Primate Biology.<ref name=":1" /> Since then, psychologists have continued to investigate personality in animals across a wide range of taxa. Meanwhile, the incorporation of animal personality into the fields of ecology and evolution is a relatively new practice. Ecologist began to recognize the importance of individual differences in behaviour near the end of the twentieth century.<ref name="Sih 372–378">{{Cite journal|last=Sih|first=Andrew|last2=Bell|first2=Alison|last3=Johnson|first3=J.Chadwick|title=Behavioral syndromes: an ecological and evolutionary overview|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0169534704001211|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=19|issue=7|pages=372–378|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2004.04.009}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
==Methods==
=== Rating of traits === Rating traits involve a group of observers that scrutinize the behavioural traits of an individual animal. Observers are typically given a list of characters and/or descriptions to use as a reference for interpreting animal behaviour then use the list to rate the behaviours.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Highfill|first=Lauren|last2=Hanbury|first2=David|last3=Kristiansen|first3=Rachel|last4=Kuczaj|first4=Stan|last5=Watson|first5=Sheree|date=2010-07-01|title=Rating vs. coding in animal personality research|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/zoo.20279|journal=Zoo Biology|language=en|volume=29|issue=4|pages=n/a–n/a|doi=10.1002/zoo.20279|issn=1098-2361}}</ref> The rating method uses observers and data recording instruments.<ref name=":2" />
=== Coding behaviours === Researchers will observe how individual animals respond to behavioural tests and code their reactions. This method is typically used in experimental studies in which environmental conditions are heavily manipulated.<ref name=":2" />
=== Behavioural reaction norms === As research in animal personality became more prevalent in ecological studies many behavioural ecologists were substituting [[Behavioral plasticity|behavioural plasticity]] for animal personality.<ref name="Sih 372–378"/> That is, attributing variation in behaviour to diverse personality types rather than plasticity in a single behavioural trait. Thus, behavioural reaction norms were introduced as a means of incorporating personality and individual plasticity in the study of animal behaviour. Behavioural reaction norms measure the behaviour of an individual over an environmental gradient, therefore providing information on how an animal behaves on average and how their behaviour changes across an environmental gradient.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Dingemanse|first=Niels J.|last2=Kazem|first2=Anahita J.N.|last3=Réale|first3=Denis|last4=Wright|first4=Jonathan|title=Behavioural reaction norms: animal personality meets individual plasticity|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0169534709002432|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=25|issue=2|pages=81–89|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2009.07.013}}</ref>
=== Repeatability === Repeatability refers to the fraction of variation in a population that is owed to differences between individuals. Repeatability estimates are one of the most widely used statistical tools that can quantify consistent individual differences in behaviour.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Biro|first=Peter A.|last2=Stamps|first2=Judy A.|title=Using repeatability to study physiological and behavioural traits: ignore time-related change at your peril|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.anbehav.2015.04.008|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=105|pages=223–230|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2015.04.008}}</ref> Formally,<math display="block">r = \left ( \frac{S_A ^2}{S_A ^2 + S^2} \right )</math>Where, <math>S_A^2
</math> is variance among individuals and <math>S^2</math> is the variance within individuals over time.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leclerc|first=Martin|last2=Wal|first2=Eric Vander|last3=Zedrosser|first3=Andreas|last4=Swenson|first4=Jon E.|last5=Kindberg|first5=Jonas|last6=Pelletier|first6=Fanie|date=2016-03-01|title=Quantifying consistent individual differences in habitat selection|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00442-015-3500-6|journal=Oecologia|language=en|volume=180|issue=3|pages=697–705|doi=10.1007/s00442-015-3500-6|issn=0029-8549}}</ref> In a meta-analysis of published, peer-reviewed repeatability estimates, reviewers found that, in general, approximately 35% of behavioural variation among individuals could be attributed to individuals differences.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bell|first=Alison M.|last2=Hankison|first2=Shala J.|last3=Laskowski|first3=Kate L.|title=The repeatability of behaviour: a meta-analysis|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0003347209000189|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=77|issue=4|pages=771–783|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2008.12.022|pmc=3972767}}</ref>
==Five Factor Model== '''The [[Five Factor Model]]''', or the Big Five personality trait model, has been used to assign personality archetypes to some animals.<ref name="Gosling2008">{{cite journal|last=Gosling|first=Samuel|title=Personality in Non-human Animals|year=2008|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/edd7/67e222a19ef713c83dd0fded4183c3cd0893.pdf|accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref> The 5 categories for the five factor model for personality are openness to experience, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism. Each of these categories identifies personality factors at the broadest level of abstraction. Because the assessment of personality using the five factor model is often a self-reported measure for humans, applying this model to animals can be difficult to standardize. Researchers often measure personality by assessing the behavior of the being over a period of time to establish the pattern. Naturally, some animals may not have as wide a range of personality as humans do. The species of the animal determines how the personality manifests itself. Likewise, a species may be predisposed to exhibit a category of personality more than other categories. So far, [[chimpanzee]]s are the only animal shown to exhibit conscientiousness.<ref name="Gosling1999">{{cite journal|last=Gosling|first=Samuel|author2=John P. Oliver|title=Personality Dimensions in Non-human Animals: A Cross-Species Review|year=1999|url=https://gosling.psy.utexas.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/CDPS99Xspeciesreview.pdf|accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref> Chimpanzees are also the only non-human species shown to demonstrate a hierarchical structure of personality, with two dimensions of affect corresponding to negative and positive emotionality, and a third dimension of disinhibition (vs. constraint), which is thought to comprise a regulatory system that is known to play a role in the perception and interpretation of incoming stimuli.{{clarify|date=October 2018}}<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Latzman, Hopkins, Keebaugh and Young|first=Robert, William, Alaine and Larry|date=21 April 2014|title=Personality in Chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes): Exploring the Hierarchical Structure and Associations with the Vasopressin V1A Receptor Gene|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3994157/pdf/pone.0095741.pdf|journal=Plus One|volume=9|pages=1-12|via=Open Access}}</ref>
Neuroticism, agreeableness and extraversion are the most commonly found personality traits among measured animals. For example, chimpanzees show emotional stability, agreeableness and surgency,<ref name="King">{{cite journal|author1=King, J.E. |author2=Figueredo, A.J. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=1997|title=The Five-Factor Model plus dominance in chimpanzee personality|journal=Journal of Research in Personality|volume=31|pages=257–271 |doi=10.1006/jrpe.1997.2179}}</ref> audiovisual reactivity, affect-extraversion,<ref name="Bard">{{cite book|author1=Bard, K.A. |author2=Gardner, K.H. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=1996|chapter=Influences on development in infant chimpanzees: Enculturation, temperament, and cognition|editor1=A.E. Russon |editor2=K.A. Bard |editor3=S.T. Parker |title=Reaching Into Thought: The Minds of the Great Apes|pages=235–256|publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, England}}</ref> excitability-agitation, aggression affinity and social play.<ref name="Hoof">{{cite book|author=Hooff, J.A.R.A.M., van.|year=1973|chapter=A structural analysis of the social behavior of a semi-captive group of chimpanzees|editor1=M. von Cranach |editor2=I. Vine |title=Social Communication and Movement: Studies of Interaction and Expression in Man and Chimpanzee|pages=75–162|publisher=Academic Press, London}}</ref>
==Correlated traits and behaviours ==
Some behaviours are correlated into a set of personality traits that remain constant throughout different situations and contexts. These traits are referred to as [[Behavioral syndrome|behavioural syndromes]]. For example, the aggressiveness-boldness syndrome refers to the correlation between an individuals aggressiveness with conspecifics and boldness in novel environments.<ref name=":4" />
Many correlated behaviours are species specific. For instance, a study in 2014 reported that for horses, personality (quantified using a validated [[questionnaire]]) and tolerance to pain (using a [[Likert scale]]) indicated that neuroticism is negatively related to stoicism whereas extroversion was positively related to levels of expressed lameness. This suggests that pain may be more easily identified in highly extrovert horses.<ref name="Ijichi">{{cite journal|author=Ijichi, C., Collins, L. M. and Elwood, R.W.|year=2014|title=Pain expression is linked to personality in horses|journal=Applied Animal Behaviour Science|volume=152|pages=38–43|doi=10.1016/j.applanim.2013.12.007}}</ref> In [[zebrafish]] (''Danio rerio''), Proactive and Reactive personalities express different thermal preferences and general activity within the temperature gradient. Proactive fish (more aggressive, bold risk-takers, prone to routine formation) have a preference for higher temperature environments. Reactive fish (shy, less risk-prone, more flexible) favor medium colder temperatures.<ref name="Rey">{{cite journal|author=Rey, S., Digka, N. and MacKenzie, S.|year=2015|title=Animal personality relates to thermal preference in wild-type zebrafish, Danio rerio|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Simon_Mackenzie/publication/274090607_Animal_Personality_Relates_to_Thermal_Preference_in_Wild-Type_Zebrafish_Danio_rerio/links/551d51ad0cf29a69c99b287c.pdf|journal=Zebrafish}}</ref>
==Evolutionary potential == The degree of variation in a population has been determined to influence to direction and outcome of natural selection. Most scientific research has focused on genetic and phenotypic variation or differences in resource use; however, variation in consistent behaviours (i.e. personality) also has important evolutionary consequences. For example, personality in animals can affect the way individuals interact with their environment and with each other which can affect the relative fitness of individuals.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Biro|first=Peter A.|last2=Stamps|first2=Judy A.|title=Are animal personality traits linked to life-history productivity?|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0169534708001596|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=23|issue=7|pages=361–368|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2008.04.003}}</ref> Therefore, personality can influence selection. Also, behavioural traits are more dynamic which may allow an animal to adapt more quickly which, in turn, can speed up the rate of evolution.<ref name=":4" />
Further, [[Natural selection|natural]] or [[artificial selection]] cannot act on personality unless there is a mechanism for its inheritance. In [[rhesus macaques]] (''Maccaca mulatta''), the personality traits of Meek, Bold, Aggressive, Passive, Loner and Nervous have heritability values of 0.14 to 0.35, thus indicated that there is some genetic basis to the expression of personality traits in animals. In [[Hominidae|apes, including humans]], heritability estimates of personality dimensions range from 0.07 to 0.63.<ref name="Brent">{{cite journal|author=Brent, L.J., Semple, S., MacLarnon, A., Ruiz-Lambides, A., Gonzalez-Martinez, J. and Platt, M.L.|year=2014|title=Personality traits in rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta) are heritable but do not predict reproductive output|journal=International Journal of Primatology|volume=35|issue=1|pages=188–209|doi=10.1007/s10764-013-9724-6|pmc=3960078}}</ref> In horses, [[heritability]] estimates range mostly between h<sup>2</sup>=0.15 and h<sup>2</sup>=0.40 for traits assessed in personality tests. Values at this level are considered as "promising" for [[artificial selection]].<ref name="Borstel">{{cite journal|author=Borstel, U.K.V.|year=2013|title=Assessing and influencing personality for improvement of animal welfare: A review of equine studies|journal=CAB Reviews|volume=8|issue=6|pages=1–27}}</ref>
==Examples== Personality in animals has been studied across a wide array of taxa. Some of these studies have investigated personality in mammals,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eggeman|first=Scott L.|last2=Hebblewhite|first2=Mark|last3=Bohm|first3=Holger|last4=Whittington|first4=Jesse|last5=Merrill|first5=Evelyn H.|date=2016-05-01|title=Behavioural flexibility in migratory behaviour in a long-lived large herbivore|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/1365-2656.12495|journal=Journal of Animal Ecology|language=en|volume=85|issue=3|pages=785–797|doi=10.1111/1365-2656.12495|issn=1365-2656}}</ref> elasmobranchs,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-59300-5_7|title=Personality in Nonhuman Animals|last=Finger|first=J. S.|last2=Dhellemmes|first2=F.|last3=Guttridge|first3=T. L.|date=2017|publisher=Springer, Cham|isbn=9783319592992|pages=129–152|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-59300-5_7}}</ref> reptiles,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Riley|first=Julia L.|last2=Noble|first2=Daniel W. A.|last3=Byrne|first3=Richard W.|last4=Whiting|first4=Martin J.|date=2017-05-01|title=Early social environment influences the behaviour of a family-living lizard|url=http://rsos.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/4/5/161082|journal=Royal Society Open Science|language=en|volume=4|issue=5|pages=161082|doi=10.1098/rsos.161082|issn=2054-5703}}</ref> fish<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Millot|first=Sandie|last2=Péan|first2=Samuel|last3=Labbé|first3=Laurent|last4=Kerneis|first4=Thierry|last5=Quillet|first5=Edwige|last6=Dupont-Nivet|first6=Mathilde|last7=Bégout|first7=Marie-Laure|date=2014-07-01|title=Assessment of Genetic Variability of Fish Personality Traits using Rainbow Trout Isogenic Lines|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10519-014-9652-z|journal=Behavior Genetics|language=en|volume=44|issue=4|pages=383–393|doi=10.1007/s10519-014-9652-z|issn=0001-8244}}</ref> and birds,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Garamszegi|first=László Zsolt|last2=Eens|first2=Marcel|last3=Török|first3=János|date=2008-07-09|title=Birds Reveal their Personality when Singing|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0002647|journal=PLOS ONE|language=en|volume=3|issue=7|pages=e2647|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0002647|issn=1932-6203}}</ref> to name just a few. [[File:Fish Laboratory in Weizmann Institute IMG 8832.JPG|thumb|Zebrafish in Fish Laboratory, Weizmann Institute.[http://www.weizmann.ac.il/mcb/GLevkowitz/] |left|240x240px]] More specifically, there have been several studies that have either been notable in that they have changed scientific understandings of animal personality or have applications in the field of human personality. For example, the study of personality in chimpanzees by King and Figueredo in 1997<ref>{{Cite journal|last=King|first=James E.|last2=Figueredo|first2=Aurelio José|title=The Five-Factor Model plus Dominance in Chimpanzee Personality|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0092656697921796|journal=Journal of Research in Personality|volume=31|issue=2|pages=257–271|doi=10.1006/jrpe.1997.2179}}</ref> was one of the first studies to apply the five-factor model in animal personality. It demonstrated the existence of personality traits in animals and provided a foundation for similar assessment strategies in future studies of personality in animals.<ref name=":1" /> Similarly, [[zebrafish]] have been used as a neurobehavioral model species for studying personality using the trait approach in non-human animals. These studies can then be translated to study personality development and personality disorders in humans.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-59300-5_6|title=Personality in Nonhuman Animals|last=Khan|first=Kanza M.|last2=Echevarria|first2=David J.|date=2017|publisher=Springer, Cham|isbn=9783319592992|pages=111–127|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-59300-5_6}}</ref>
Another general example is the spider, ''[[Anelosimus studiosus]].'' This spider forms groups in which some females show an aggressive personality type and engage more in colony defence and prey capture, while others are docile and engage more in brood care. Groups containing both these two different personalities have better fitness than groups of only one personality type. This is because aggressive females are more efficient at foraging, web construction and defence, while docile females are better at raising the young. When groups contain a mix of both personalities, overall group performance is improved benefiting all group members.<ref name="Grinsted">{{cite journal|author1=Grinsted, L. |author2=Bacon, J.P. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2014|title=Animal behaviour: Task differentiation by personality in spider groups|journal=Current Biology|volume=24|issue=16|pages=R749-R751|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982214008343 |doi=10.1016/j.cub.2014.07.008 |pmid=25137587}}</ref> In the social spider ''Stegodyphus dumicola'' individuals differ in their boldness, with bolder individuals having a greater risk appetite. Boldness changes were found to relate to social interactions with nest mates, indicating that individual personality is more plastic in groups.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Hunt, ER. |title= Social interactions shape individual and collective personality in social spiders |journal= Proceedings of the Royal Society B |year= 2018 |volume= 285 |issue= 1886 |doi=10.1098/rspb.2018.1366|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==Criticism== Many researchers are critical of the lack of consistency in the terminology surrounding animal personality. For example, temperament, behavioural syndrome, disposition and animal personality have been used interchangeably by some while others maintain that each term has a unique meaning.<ref name=":0" /> Additionally, there is some concern that researchers may be misinterpreting the relationship between personality and behavioural plasticity. The behavioural ecologist, Dr. Niels Dingemanse, illustrates that one could erroneously determine that variation in behaviour between individuals exists if the subjects have not been examined across a gradient of ecological contexts and urges fellow researchers to apply behavioural reaction norms whenever possible.<ref name=":3" /> In addition, because of [[critical anthropomorphism]], [[ethology]], and [[comparative psychology]] are relatively unknown concepts to the layman, there are critics that question the validity in the claim that animals have a personality schema. There are those that fear that, while assessing behaviors, researchers will project anthropomorphic ratings onto the animals.<ref name="Gosling1999" />
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} [[File:Day 40 Occupy Wall Street October 25 2011 Shankbone 19.JPG|thumb|right|Reverend Billy at [[Occupy Wall Street]], where he performed in support of the movement.]]
'''Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping''' is a radical performance community based in New York City. The Stop Shopping Choir is accompanied by a comic preacher, Reverend Billy. The philosophy of the Church of Stop Shopping surrounds the imminent "Shopocalypse", which assumes the end of humanity will come about through manic [[consumerism]].<ref name=mcclish> {{Cite journal|last=McClish|first=Carmen L|title=Activism based in embarrassment: The anti-consumption spirituality of the Reverend Billy|journal=Liminalities: A Journal of Performance Studies|volume=5.2 (2009)|pages=1-20}}</ref>
The Stop Shopping Choir accompanies Reverend Billy and stages [[Guerrilla theatre|guerrilla theater]] style actions, singing on the property of the [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] stores,<ref name=burke> {{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/monteburke/2011/04/21/reverend-billy-and-his-crusade-against-consumerism/2/|title=Reverend Billy and His Crusade Against Consumerism|last=Burke|first=Monte|date=April 21, 2011|work=Forbes|access-date=October 5, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> [[Monsanto]] facilities,<ref name=burke/> and [[Trump Tower]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-activists-who-are-staging-acts-of-protest-inside-trump-tower|title=The Activists Who Are Staging Protest in Trump Tower.|last=Moynihan|first=Colin|date=June 14, 2017|work=The New Yorker|access-date=October 5, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> among others. They are often considered part of the [[Culture Jamming]] movement.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Like moths to a flame: culture jamming and the global spectacle.|last=Wettergren|first=Åsa|work=Representing Resistance: Media, Civil Disobedience, and the Global Justice Movement|publisher=Praeger|year=2003|editor-last=Opel|editor-first=Andrew|location=Westport, Conn.|pages=27-43|editor-last2=Pompper|editor-first2=Donnalyn}}</ref>
The group uses the content from their direct actions to create songs that are performed on concert stages and in cabarets. The director of these shows is church co-founder Savitri D. The music director is Nehemiah Luckett. Reverend Billy and the Stop Shopping Choir routinely perform at [[Joe's Pub]] at [[The Public Theater]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/lypsinka-reverend-billy-and-tori-scott-coming-to-joes-pub-may-11-18|title=John Epperson, Reverend Billy, and Tori Scott Coming to Joe's Pub May 11–18|last=Viagas|first=Robert|date=October 5, 2017|website=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Origins of Reverend Billy==
[[File:RevBilly1.jpg|thumb|left|Reverend Billy attempting to exorcise bad loans and toxic assets from the Bank of America ATM in Union Square, New York City, 2009]]
The character of Reverend Billy was developed in the early 1990s by actor and playwright, William Talen. His family was Dutch Calvinist,<ref name=kalb>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/27/arts/spring-theater-visions-america-downtown-gospel-according-reverend-billy.html|title=The Downtown Gospel According to Reverend Billy|last=Kalb|first=Jonathan|date=February 27, 2000|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 5, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> from the [[Christian Reformed Church in North America|Christian Reformed Church]], a conservative sect concentrated in Holland and Grand Rapids, Michigan. The precepts of this kind of [[Christianity]] were the basis for Dutch [[Afrikaners]] system of [[Apartheid]] in South Africa.{{cn|date=November 2018}}
Talen grew up in small towns throughout Minnesota, South Dakota and Wisconsin. He left home at 16, moving east with Charles and Patricia Gaines, a writer and painter who encouraged him as an artist. Talen began to perform his poems and stories, hitch-hiking from Philadelphia to New York to San Francisco.<ref name=jacobs> {{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/profile-of-william-talen-better-known-as-reverend-billy-2015-2?r=UK&IR=T|title=The craziest thing about this legendary singing, anti-corporate preacher is that he isn't real|last=Jacobs|first=Harrison|date=February 4, 2015|work=Business Insider|access-date=March 29, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref>
Talen's chief collaborator in developing the Reverend Billy character was the Reverend Sidney Lanier, a cousin of [[Tennessee Williams]].<ref name=kalb/> Lanier was vicar of The [[Church of St. Clement Mary Hofbauer|St. Clement's]] in the 1960s, an Episcopal Church in [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]] in [[Manhattan]].<ref name=kalb/> In an effort to increase attendance at St. Clement's, Lanier had torn out the altar and pews, inviting actors to perform scenes from plays by Tennessee Williams and Terrence McNally, and founding founding the American Place Theater. Lanier described Talen as "more of a preacher with a gift for social prophecy than an actor.<nowiki>''</nowiki><ref name=kalb/> In the early 1990s Talen moved with Lanier to New York City from the San Francisco Bay Area, branding his act as a "new kind of American preacher"<ref name=jacobs/>
The Reverend Billy character debuted on the sidewalk at Times Square in 1998, outside the Disney Store, where he proclaimed Mickey Mouse to be the anti-Christ.<ref name=kalb/> He was arrested multiple times outside the Disney Store, where he duct-tapped Mickey Mouse to a cross.<ref name=Kasperkevic>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/nov/27/reverend-billy-church-of-stop-shopping-black-friday|title=The Church of Stop Shopping doesn't pull punches on its return to New York.|last=Kasperkevic|first=Jana|date=November 27, 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=October 8, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> Reverend Billy's sermons decried the evils of [[consumerism]] and the racism of sweatshop labor, and what Talen saw as the loss of neighborhood spirit in [[Rudy Giuliani|Rudolph Giuliani]]'s New York.<ref name=jacobs/>
The Reverend Billy character isn't so much a parody of a preacher, as a preacher motif used to blur the lines between performance and religious experience. "It's definitely a church service," Talen explained to ''Altnernet'', but, he added, it's "a political rally, it's theater, it's all three, it's none of them."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.alternet.org/story/29476/the_reluctant_religion_of_reverend_billy|title=The Reluctant Religion of Reverend Billy|last=Tytel|first=Brad|date=December 12, 2005|work=Alternet|access-date=April 1, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> Alisa Solomon, the theater critic at the [[The Village Voice|Village Voice]], said of Reverend Billy's persona, "The collar is fake, the calling is real."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2000/03/14/never-can-say-good-buy/|title=Never Can Say Good Buy|last=Solomon|first=Alisa|date=March 14, 2000|work=The Village Voice|access-date=October 8, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> Along with the Church of Stop Shopping, they have been referred to by academics as "performance activism,"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Perucci|first=Tony|year=2009|title=What the Fuck is That?: The Poetics of Ruptural Performance|journal=Liminalities: A Journal of Performance Studies|volume=5.3|pages=1-18}}</ref> "carnivalesque protest,"<ref name="mcclish" /> and "commercial disobedience."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/22/magazine/reverend-billy-s-unholy-war.html|title=Reverend Billy's Unholy War.|last=Dee|first=Jonathan|date=August 22, 2004|work=The New York Times Magazine|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Savitri D, church co-founder and theatrical director==
Savitri D (née Durkee) is the co-founder and director of the Church of Stop Shopping, as well as Talen's partner.<ref name=kolbert>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/05/19/buzzkill-2|title=Buzzkill|last=Kolbert|first=Elizabeth|date=May 19, 2014|work=The New Yorker|access-date=March 29, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> She was born in [[Taos, New Mexico]] in 1972. She was raised at [[Lama Foundation|The Lama Foundation]], one of the earliest and longest lasting intentional spiritual communities in the US, founded by her parents, Steven and Barbara Durkee.<ref>Banner, Lois W. "Finding Fran: History and Memory in the Lives of Two Women", Columbia University Press, 1998, p. 173. {{ISBN|0-231-11216-5}}</ref>
Savitri D began dancing and performing at the University of Montana, studied at the [[Merce Cunningham]] Dance Company, and co-founded a dance collective called The Zen Monkey Project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.zenmonkeyproject.com/history/|title=History of Past Performances|website=Zen Monkey Project|dead-url=}}</ref> After moving to New York City in 1997, she staged her play SKY/NO SKY at 57 Walker Street<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://franklinfurnace.org/goings_on/recent_goings_on/2003/03_03_13.php|title=Franklin Furnace's Goings On|date=March 13, 2003|website=Franklin's Furnace|dead-url=|access-date=March 31, 2018}}</ref>.
In 2000, she was a producer at The Culture Project, a theater in the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]], where Talen was staging early Reverend Billy performances.<ref name=jacobs/> She took over direction of The Church of Stop Shopping performances from the dramatist Tony Torn<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/reviews/03-2000/reverend-billy_350.html|title=Reviews: Reverend Billy|last=Josh|first=Godfrey|date=March 17, 2000|work=Theater Mania|access-date=March 31, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> in the aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001, and married Talen the next year.<ref name=jacobs/>
Under Savitri D's leadership, the Church won the Alpert Award for Theater<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://herbalpertawards.org/artist/2010/bill-talen|title=The Herb Alpert Award in the Arts|website=The Herb Alpert Awards|dead-url=}}</ref> and the Edwin Booth Award<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc.cuny.edu/Page-Elements/Academics-Research-Centers-Initiatives/Doctoral-Programs/Theatre/Doctoral-Theatre-Students-Association-(DTSA)/Booth-Award|title=Booth Award, Previous Award Recipients|website=The Graduate Center, CUNY|dead-url=}}</ref> from the [[City University of New York]].
==The Stop Shopping Choir==
The Stop Shopping Choir is a 35-member ensemble that performs an array of original gospel songs in theater performances and alongside Reverend Billy in public spaces during campaigns.<ref name=revbilly.com>{{Cite web|url=http://www.revbilly.com/about_the_stop_shopping_choir|title=About The Stop Shopping Choir|website=revbilly.com|dead-url=|access-date=April 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/16/nyregion/reverend-billy-brings-a-new-sermon-to-joes-pub.html|title=Reverend Billy Brings a New Sermon to Joe's Pub|last=Lee|first=A.C.|date=May 15, 2014|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 2, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> The choir began accompanying Talen's sermons at concert shows shortly after the [[September 11 attacks]], adding a musical influence to Reverend Billy performances.<ref name=jacobs/> Led by musical director Nehemiah Luckett,<ref name=revbilly.com/> the choir members are volunteers who rehearse weekly at the Lower Eastside Girl's Club in the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/if-monsanto-loses-its-name-what-will-its-haters-have-left-to-hate-1477402968|title=If Monsanto Loses Its Name, What Will Its Haters Have Left to Hate?|last=Bunge|first=Jacob|date=October 15, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=April 2, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref>
The Choir often write songs that draw attention to the environmental and consumerist campaigns championed by the Church of Stop Shopping. They have accompanied Talen into the lobbies of multinational banks such as JP Morgan Chase or research facilities belonging to Monsanto, dressed as golden toads and honeybees, singing songs in support of the day's sermon. One of their best-known songs is The First Amendment, an incantation of the 1st Amendment of the [[United States Constitution]], sung rapturously by soprano Laura Newman.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.revbilly.com/the_first_amendment_song|title=The First Amendment Song|website=revbilly.com|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Direct Action Campaigns==
In addition to protest performances throughout a given year, Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping have organized various campaigns focused on consumerist or environmental issues, often highlighting a particular company they feel best symbolizes the issue. The group stage actions in public spaces near the targets of their actions, or in the lobbies, halls, and plazas of the building owned by the companies they protest. Their sermons and songs routinely draw the attention of police and security forces assigned to those spaces, leading to arrests and significant media coverage. Talen and Savitri D have been arrested more than 50 times during their actions, though their charges are almost always reduced or dropped.<ref name=jacobs/>
===Early campaigns=== Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping staged numerous actions around New York City in their formative years. In 2000, after performing a Christmas show the [[The New School|New School]]'s Tishman Auditorium, Reverend Billy led the congregation and members of the audience from the stage to the [[Edgar Allan Poe House (Manhattan)|Poe House]] on West 3rd Street in Manhattan's [[West Village]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/merry-christmas-rev-billy-performance-preacher-hosts-poe-service-dec-16-com-93856|title=Merry Christmas, Rev. Billy: Performance Preacher Hosts Poe Service Dec. 16|last=Ehren|first=Christine|date=December 16, 2000|work=Playbill|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref> There, the Reverend held a protest reading of "[[The Raven]]" atop the scaffolding over the soon-to-be-demolished home where [[Edgar Allan Poe|Edgar Allen Poe]] had finished writing the famous poem. After the reading, Talen was arrested and jailed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playloud.org/archiveandstore/en/dvd/60-reverend-billy.html|title=Reverend Billy & The Church of Stop Shopping|last=Post|first=Dietmar|last2=Palacios|first2=Lucía|year=2002|website=playloud!|dead-url=}}</ref>
After [[September 11 attacks|September 11]], the Church and Choir met routinely in the [[PATH (rail system)|Path Station]] near [[World Trade Center site|Ground Zero]] and sang the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution]] into their phones as commuters passed by. The crowd of singers sometimes reached up to 200 participants.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/He-s-a-preacher-of-sorts-who-has-found-his-2764879.php|title=He's a preacher -- of sorts -- who has found his calling: rooting out the evils of consumerism, block by entertaining block|last=Ganahl|first=Jane|date=April 24, 2004|work=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
On June 29, 2007, just before the start of the monthly [[Critical Mass (cycling)|Critical Mass bike]] ride, Reverend Billy and Savitri D recited the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] repeatedly to police officers through a megaphone in Manhattan's Union Square. Reverend Billy was arrested on charges of second-degree harassment.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/26/nyregion/26billy.html|title=A Street Performer Crusades for the First Amendment|last=Hartocollis|first=Anemona|date=September 26, 2007|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref> The civil liberties lawyer [[Norman Siegel]] defended Reverend Billy in court, saying "Reverend Billy has a First Amendment right to recite the First Amendment."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/01/nyregion/01billy.html|title=A Pretend Preacher, a Real Arrest and a Debate About Free Speech|last=Wilensky-Lanford|first=Ethan|date=July 1, 2007|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
===Starbucks=== The Church of Stop Shopping staged a series of actions across the country from 2002 to 2008, protesting against what they call Starbucks company's enactment of "fake bohemia." Reverend Billy and the singers tried to "exorcise the demon of cookie-cutter capitalism" from its cash registers, by laying hands on the register, weeping, and harmonizing.<ref name=Kasperkevic/>
The [[Starbucks]] coffee chain has been a frequent target of the Church's actions, due to displacement of small local businesses,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.urbandisplacement.org/case-studies/ucla#section-91|title=Impact of Big Businesses in Chinatown|last=Macedo|first=Edber|last2=Fang|first2=Jimmy|date=July 1, 2014|website=UCLA Case Studies|dead-url=|access-date=November 12, 2017|last3=Le|first3=Thomas|last4=Ong|first4=Paul M.}}</ref> [[union busting]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/zp-heller/spilling-the-beans-about_b_205497.html|title=Spilling the Beans About Starbucks' Union-Busting Tactics|last=Heller|first=ZP|date=May 25, 2011|work=HuffPost|access-date=November 12, 2017|dead-url=}}</ref> and exploitation of coffee farmers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/8355026|title=Storm in a coffee cup: Starbucks vs Ethiopia.|date=November 30, 2006|work=The Economist|access-date=April 23, 2018|dead-url=}}</ref>
In 2002, Starbucks branches throughout New York City issued a document to its workers entitled "What Should I do If Reverend Billy Is in My Store?",<ref name=talen>{{Cite web|url=http://thenewpress.com/books/what-should-i-do-if-reverend-billy-my-store|title=What Should I Do if Reverend Billy is in My Store|last=Talen|first=Bill|date=April 1, 2005|website=New York Press|dead-url=}}</ref> which outlines an evacuation protocol and a series of scripted reassurances that workers are ordered to deliver to disturbed or inquisitive customers. The title of the document is also the title of a book written by Talen, published by The New Press.<ref name=talen/>
In 2004, Starbucks persuaded a Los Angeles judge to issue an injunction against Talen, demanding that he cease and desist from "stalking, contacting, or sexually harassing the computerized cash registers of the Starbucks Company."<ref name=talen/>
===Golden Toads and Bank Actions=== In 2012 and 2013, Reverend Billy and the Church focused on the extinction of species brought by climate change, specifically targeting banks they said financed projects that worsened global warming. The symbolic centerpiece of these campaigns was the extinct [[Golden toad]], originally native to [[Monteverde Cloud Forest Reserve|Monteverde cloud forest]] in Costa Rica and a symbol for the crisis of [[Decline in amphibian populations|declining amphibian species]]. Savitri D and the choir wore papier mâché masks depicting golden toads as they entered JP Morgan Chase and HSBC banks.<ref name=vidal>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/nov/25/reverend-billy-jpmorgan-chase-toad-protest-talen|title=Reverend Billy faces year in prison for JP Morgan Chase toad protest|last=Vidal|first=John|date=November 25, 2013|work=The Guardian|access-date=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
In one action in a Chase bank in New York City, Reverend Billy and choir director Nehemiah Luckett were arrested and charged with riot, trespass, unlawful assembly, and disorderly conduct. According to the bank manager in a complaint to police, Reverend Billy and the choir were "running about the bank while wearing frog masks … jumping on to the bank's furniture, running about the bank, and screaming loudly at others for a number of minutes." The manager also stated that he thought the bank was being robbed, that he feared for his safety, and that customers or bank employees even cried.<ref name=vidal/>
Despite the complaints against them and what the New York prosecutor called a "criminal stunt," demanding that Talen go to prison for a year, their charges were eventually dropped.<ref name=kolbert/>
===British Petroleum and Liberate Tate=== As part of the Church of Stop Shopping's efforts to urge art institutions to reject sponsorship from petroleum companies, they have protested at a number of museums around the world.<ref name=vidaltate>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2011/jul/19/reverend-billy-tate-modern-bp|title=Reverend Billy leads exorcism of BP's 'evil spirit' from Tate Modern|last=Vidal|first=John|date=July 19, 2011|work=The Guardian|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
In July 2011, while on tour in the UK, Reverend Billy and the Choir staged an action at the Tate Modern in London to protest its sponsorship by the oil company British Petroleum (BP). The church was invited by a coalition of UK groups, including Liberate Tate, BP or Not BP, Platform, UK Tar Sands Network, London Rising Tide, Art Not Oil and Climate Rush.<ref name=vidaltate/>
While crowds observed the scene in the Turbine Room of the Tate, the choir splashed Reverend Billy and the BP sunflower logo with bottles of black oil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=luoL5A-SHQk|title=Reverend Billy exorcizes BP at Tate Modern|last=Talen|first=Billy|date=July 19, 2011|via=YouTube|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> After the performance, the protesters exited the museum singing onto the lawn outside, and rallied on the shore of the Thames against oil companies and their involvement in the arts.<ref name=vidaltate/>
===Robobees===
In 2014, Reverend Billy, Savitri D and the Choir turned their focus to [[colony collapse disorder]] affecting the world's honeybees. In one action, they entered the Micro-robotics Laboratory at Harvard's School of Engineering and Applied Science to confront scientists working on the invention of robot pollinators, popularly known as RoboBees. They purchased fruits and vegetables to place before a display case with a model of the RoboBee, singing and lamenting the focus of scientists replacing living bees with robots, rather than solving the collapse.<ref name=forde>{{Cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/6/2/robotic-bee-project.html|title=Taking off from Harvard Yard: Flight of the RoboBees|last=Forde|first=Kaelyn|date=June 2, 2014|publisher=Al Jazeera|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
“We ask you to place your genius, your research, your scientific know-how into ''saving'' the honeybee," Talen said to those assembled. Attending the event and writing for [[The New Yorker]], [[Elizabeth Kolbert]] noted the confusion among some of the Harvard graduate students witnessing the singing and preaching. "We like people not to know if we're a political rally, a religious service, or a theatrical comedy about a church," Reverend Billy told Kolbert. "If they have all three spinning in their head, and they can't settle on one, then they're probably having a raw experience."<ref name=kolbert/>
===Monsanto=== The Church of Stop Shopping has also targeted chemical manufacturer [[Monsanto]] for its production of [[Glyphosate|glysophate]] herbicides and [[neonicotinoid]] pesticides.<ref name=forde/> In November 2014, the Church traveled to Monsanto's headquarters in [[St. Louis|St. Louis, Missouri]], where they held an "Organic Thanksgiving."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/events/1490386454559843/|title=Organic Thanksgiving at Monsanto World Headquarters|date=November 24, 2014|website=|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}</ref>
In 2015, Reverend Billy & The Stop Shopping Choir opened a series of shows for [[Neil Young]] during his tour in support of ''[[The Monsanto Years]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://diffuser.fm/fellow-monsanto-opponent-reverend-billy-to-open-for-neil-young-in-nyc/|title=Fellow Monsanto Opponent Reverend Billy to Open for Neil Young in NYC|last=Rossignol|first=Derrick|date=July 3, 2015|website=Diffuser|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
On October 13, 2016, Reverend Billy was arrested while protesting the [[World Food Prize]] in [[Des Moines, Iowa]]. He was charged with trespass for leaving the "free speech area" set up near the event.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hyperallergic.com/342380/a-performance-troupe-takes-on-immigration-monsanto-and-standing-rock/|title=A Performance Troupe Takes on Immigration, Monsanto, and Standing Rock|last=Hamm|first=Theodore|date=December 2, 2016|work=Hyperallergenic|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> The prosecutor for the state requested "that the Court preclude evidence or argument regarding 'free speech rights,' 'free expression,'right to assemble,' and/or other First Amendment arguments and evidence that 'free speech rights' can constitute 'justification' under the Iowa's criminal trespass statute, Iowa Code §716.7 (2015)."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://d3n8a8pro7vhmx.cloudfront.net/revbilly/pages/857/attachments/original/1483909235/Motion_in_Limine_-_Trepassing_Cases_(Talen___Cordaro)_(1).PDF?1483909235|title=STATE'S MOTION IN LIMINE, AND/OR FOR 5.104(A) RULING|date=January 2, 2017|website=|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> The judge in the case ultimately dismissed the charges.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2017/01/monsanto-amendment-170124075931929.html|title=On Monsanto and the First Amendment|last=Talen|first=Billy|date=January 24, 2017|publisher=Al Jazeera|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
In 2016, the Church released a guide called "The United States Map of Poisoned Parks and Playgrounds," which shows the dosage and location of glyphosate applications around the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.revbilly.com/nationalmap|title=U.S. Map of Poisoned Parks and Playgrounds|website=revbilly.com|dead-url=|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
